awd_titl_txt: EAGER:  SCALE 2 (Safe Community Awareness and Alerting) - Extending a SmartAmerica Challenge Project
awd_abstract_narration:
SCALE2 explores the design of resilient, inexpensive cyber-physical systems (CPS) technologies to create community-wide smartspaces for public/personal safety. SCALE2 aims to demonstrate that community safety can be realized by augmenting CPS technologies with end-to-end resilience mechanisms. Such a study requires real-world community-scale deployments to understand citizen concerns and can only be achieved through partnerships between various stakeholders - researchers, government agencies, and industry.

The SCALE2 multisensory platform will use inexpensive Internet of things (IoT) components, and support dependable operation by enabling resilient information-flow through multiple system layers. Research will explore mechanisms for (a) ingest of real-time data through flexible rich data models, (b) Quality of Service (QoS)-aware messaging to cloud platforms, and (c) reliable detection of higher-level community events through semantics-driven virtual sensing. SCALE2, through its established partnerships/testbeds, offers a unique short-term opportunity to guide future resilience technologies, train the next generation of students and have broader community impact. SCALE2 will be deployed at Montgomery County, MD, and the Irvine-Sensorium working with local agencies.

por.por_cntn:
SCALE2 (Safe Community Awareness and Alerting), a Global Cities Challenge Project is a community government/academic/industry partnership effort that aims to deploy, actuate and evaluate techniques to support multiple heterogeneous IoT technologies in real world communities. SCALE was initiated as a part of the SmartAmerica Challenge to create new platforms and applications that leverage emerging IoT technologies. The SCALE2 IoT platform (SCALEbox) leverages inexpensive off-the​-shelf sensors and diverse communication technologies  (Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, ZigBee, 3G and UNB) to create an IoT multinetworking architecture. SCALE2 software includes an event-​driven publish-subscribe based middleware platform where devices upload sensed events to a cloud or edge data exchange where services (for analytics, notification etc.) can retrieve events. SCALE2 focuses on exploring and integrating resilience technologies at different layers to ensure reliable operation of the end-to-end platform. SCALE2 was successfully deployed in the Victory Senior Housing, the Thingstitute makerspace in Montgomery County, MD and at UC Irvine, CA for applications such as personal safety for seniors, public safety in seismic and fire events, environmental monitoring (air quality) in smart spaces and safety/security in smart buildings. SCALE2 platforms have also been deployed in other nations around the world including Taiwan and Bangladesh for community scale IoT efforts,

Through this project, we developed a range of resilience methods to improve the reliability of multisensor information capture, delivery and information processing at different endpoints in the cloud to things continuum. Techniques for resilient communications in SCALE includes the design of resilient  overlay networks and multicast protocols to support decentralized, localized sensemaking.  We developed and explored the notion of GEOgraphically Correlated Resilient Overlay Networks (GeoCRON) to capture the localized nature of community IoT deployments and their impact/vulnerability in the context of small failures and massive disruptions such as that caused by a large seismic event. We studied the impact of geo-​correlated failures on the combined network infrastructure and illustrated the utility  of GeoCRON algorithms.

To support resilience at the edge, we designed and developed RIDE (Resilient IoT Data Exchange), a service-oriented middleware that extends publish-subscribe platforms  to monitor cloud networks and cloud service availability.. RIDE utilizes software-defined networking (SDN) mechanisms for collecting cloud availability information (RIDE-C),  diverts network traffic to an edge server through flow routing and flow prioritization techniques and enables reliable awareness dissemination (RIDE-D) using resilient multicast in an edge network. We implemented RIDE on a SDN test-bed using an OpenFlow​-capable switch and a distributed ONOS controller with a REST API adapter.

New methods for resilient information gathering that combines the use of insitu and mobile sensors through cooperative planning (scheduling  and upload) were developed - the use of mobility via shared bicycles and public transit buses  were studied. In larger deployments, we explored the use of participatory mobile sensing to let citizens participate with their personal devices, captured spatiotemporal impact of multiple sensor types that generate heterogeneous data at different levels of granularity and planed sensor calibration and maintenance in to improve the overall efficiency in smart building and smart campus scenarios.

Finally, this project explored novel application environments for perpetual awareness in SCALE (environmental sensing in developing nations, personal safety in assisted living environments) that raised new constraints. We developed research techniques to handle limited use data plans in developing nations and energy usage concerns in assisted living deployments.

The project has trained several graduate students ( Ph.D. and M.S) whose work focused on addressing resilience concerns at the network and data collection layers. K-12 outreach was realized through programs such as the  IoTSITY Site REU and via high school students working on SCALE related projects.  The SCALE software platform and hardware design is available via open platforms; research results have been disseminated via several publications and talks in top tier venues.   Community outreach efforts include partnerships with local governments at the city/county level and with public safety and public works agencies. SCALE has also instantiated new efforts that address  challenges in focused domains (e.g. healthcare, environmental monitoring, water infrastructure resilience).
